turn.text: Not -- not in this case either.

If this case now goes back, if you prevail and this goes back but as you said this bank's title encumbered with the Government's lien nevertheless accept as the property would you bring more than the bank's original loan with the expense and everything else without it -- the Government gets nothing.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's precisely correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And if on the -- on the second sale the property brought more money than -- than the original lien plus your lien the surplus would go back to the first lienholder.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: To the -- yes -- (Voice overlap) -- to the -- to the owner of the property, to the owner of the property.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well I thought you recognized that the State had the right to wipe out the -- to wipe out rights of the -- of the owner of the property under -- under state law.
I thought you were only interested in your lien.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Then they write -- wipe out the rights of the owner in the state law but as I understand state law if there is any excess over and above the amount necessary to satisfy all the prior claims that then goes back to the owner of the property.
That's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But I -- I did not understand -- at least Mr. Stewart -- I'm -- I'm going to give Mr. Steward five minutes to -- to respond.
When this is over and you make take five minutes more too Mr. Friedman --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- because I think there are some things that we'd like to hear from him.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: To my understanding --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But I thought that when one may when -- on the original sale I -- I thought so far as private lienholders were concerned that those were wiped out and the State according to the state's procedure and you -- you agreed to that.
It's only your -- your only objection as to wiping out the government's lien.
Now if you come in and have a second -- a second sale, are you going to reestablish the rights of the junior lienholders?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well I'm not clear to your question Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well let me put it -- let me put it this way, take the -- the case that -- that Mr. -- Mr. Justice Brennan submitted to you.
Suppose that the -- the bank loaned $25,000.00.
The tax due is $5,000.00.
They first foreclose the -- the property and wiped you out.
Then they bring this action to quiet title as against the -- the Government.
On the -- on the resale of the property, there is a bid of $50,000.00.
That would give you back or give the bank back its $25,000.00, it would give the Government its $5,000.00 and make $30,000.00 -- where would the other $20,000.00 go?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I would think it would go back to the original owner Mr. Chief Justice because the whole purpose of these interests are security interest.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well -- But --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Now if the property were sold for less than the principal amount --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The interest I -- it's clear too.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's not -- there's nothing left.
I would think that if there was -- and the property would sell to more than the principle amount of the indebtedness plus all liens, any additional amount would revert to the owner of the property.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
Well I do not want to prolong it but I -- my -- my only confusion was this.

I thought -- I thought that you recognized that through this power of sale and the -- and the sale itself that the state had the right to wipe out the interest of the owner and -- and all junior liens with the exception of the United States Government and -- and because the Government is the Government they can't do -- do that, but now, if -- if that is true and if they didn't wipe out those rights, why should you, through this kind of an action, reestablish their rights?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well we -- we're -- whatever effect this would have on their right under the state law is a matter which is not a concern of ours.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well -- well that's the point that I'm trying to put before this Court in respect of lien.(Laughter)

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: When I -- I think -- trying to ask you a question -- when -- when --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But you're always trying to get a --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Your Honor --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It's not -- not your worry.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes but --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Although I have it the Chief Justice is understanding of what Mr. Stewart told us or told me in regards to California law.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well it -- I may be in error in California law.
Mr. Stewart knows more about it than I do.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They're not a part of this suit are they?
You only represent the United States.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: May I ask you one more question?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Is it your position that this exercise of the power to sale (Inaudible) and what it did not satisfy or displace any liens.
Now they have to go back and start all over under Section 7424 or 7403 to foreclose, is that your idea?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No -- no, Mr. Justice.
We don't claim that the exercise of the power to sale under state law is void.
We claim that the exercise of the power of sale whatever its effect maybe as between the private parties does not have the effect of eliminating our lien on the property.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But it didn't eliminate the lien foreclosed and all other liens?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is as far as state law provides, yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And that's then you say leaves your lien (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you don't -- I think that you declared that as a -- did that sound like you are saying that if you win this lawsuit, the bank is going to lose money and can't collect its mortgage and debt, you don't mean that.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Of course not Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What you mean as I understand is that the Government is that you're right on the statute, it authorizes a suit to quiet title, you say that they're authorized to file that the procedure that in the merits they shouldn't win because that you interpret the federal statute, they can't take away the Government's right without a notice, by making it a party to a lawsuit.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Precisely.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And so if you get it back and nobody else try to litigate but you and them that you -- that you're engaged, you said a while ago that you have no interest in them – (Inaudible).
What you want is a chance to see whether or not the Government has been injured by having it foreclosed without notice.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Precisely.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As you say the statute requires.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And is there anything else in it except whether the statute requires it.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: We don't think so we -- and I want to emphasize that the bank cannot possibly be hurt financially because we don't claim a penny until the mortgage has been fully satisfied.
If there's not enough in this property to produce anything more than the amount of the bank's indebtedness, we don't get anything.
No one is hurt.
All that we say is we'd like to have an opportunity as Congress has provided to give us a chance to make that determination.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you don't say that by their attempting to display surely and as you say wrongfully they thereby forfeited their mortgage or any part of it.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Oh no, of course not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: On the other hand you mustn't -- you mustn't belittle their claim because they don't lose anything.

The point is that they have certain interest which they think they have acquired under state law on which they stand and the right to the property is also -- maybe allowed by state law and that maybe a right which is what they are asserting here.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Surely.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It has nothing to do with your claim.
All I'm saying is you -- you must have been to appear that the act -- Mr. Stewart here is representing an abstract proposition of law.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No I -- I -- all I was suggesting is that there is no -- in -- unfairness to the bank.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that's it.
This all depends what their rights were on -- what their rights were when (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I was going to suggest there is no unfairness to the bank in holding that the federal lien is not eliminated by exercise of the power of sale since the bank -- since the United States cannot realize any of the proceeds until the bank's prior claim has been paid in full.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I suppose that practically speaking from the Government standpoint or any other there are many instances in which foreclosure sails ahead rather just bring totally and completely inadequate amount and that if it's sold for what they were worth they would pay off the mortgage and pay off the other liens and you are claiming that the federal statute provides that you should be given notice in order to protect your right that you may have.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes in any of the -- any access over and above the value.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Could I ask you a question at this point?
Supposing the conclusion has come to the federal statutes do not prohibit what was done here, what is your position at that point?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: You mean that the federal statute permits --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: That this federal statute does not make this as an exclusive procedure which is the basis of your argument.

Have you got a constitutional first to your argument then that if the state law governs and if the state law purports to take away the Government's lien hereby extinguish them and then whatever words you want to call it, that -- that violates due process or --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, we are not making a constitution --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: You are not making a constitutional argument.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, because if -- if this Court concludes that Congress determined that the validity to continued existence of federal liens is to be determined by state court procedures that's the end of our position.

And indeed Mr. Justice I want to repeat once again that Congress specifically so decided in one provision of 2410 where it said, that in the event there is a judicial sale, a foreclosure at a judicial sale then the effect of all liens will be determined as they are under local law, but for that to happen there must be a -- the United States must be made a party to a foreclosure suit and there must be a judicial foreclosure.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: So your -- your whole position as it stands on the – stems from your argument that the federal statutes are the exclusive means of destroying a Government lien.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Precisely that.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: That's all there is.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That -- that is our basic claim.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Stewart is going to say yes to that proposition too?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well I'd like --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Because you're constructing what -- construing what the federal statute says as any question exclusiveness.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Its -- it's exclusiveness in the sense that Congress has determined the procedures for the discharge of federal liens and has not permitted the States by the exercise of their own procedures affecting State interest also to wipe out federal --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I could sense that answer of yours and not answer your problem at all because you have to go on to the next step what is it that Congress has provided?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: What Congress has provided --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Because how big your argument -- I know what it is.
All I'm saying is you're speaking -- maybe answered yes I believe by Mr. Stewart and come out just the opposite.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well I think the -- the answer in the following --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In other words it means that the question of what 2410 means and what it is saying is it's quite within the statute is whether to choose to quiet title etcetera, etcetera and you say that a suit to quiet title can -- can start with the answer which Congress only to have answered by the litigation.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: The suit if I may suggest Mr. Justice, the suit to quiet title cannot prevail because the title isn't quieted that the Congress had said that you cannot use these state procedures to eliminate the federal lien.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You're saying in effect that 2410 means if they can't take away the Government's title to that lien without notice to the Government making it a party under 2410?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Precisely and I cannot --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Whatever else they can do if they can't do that.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's precisely --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well now one other thing so if this gets back to the question I asked you yesterday, the discussion you and I had yesterday.

I gather and may I use the example I did yesterday the foreclosure of the suit so you've got my own state policy to know what I'm really familiar with I gather is in a New Jersey foreclosure procedure the government is given notice and is made a party in circumstances like this.
Then except for that the procedure is there's the notice for the Government must be those described by 2410.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And the Government will have the right to remove that action to the federal court --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- if they desire but the judicial sale which eventually then satisfies 2410.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But it's -- and where they have different forms of procedures as apparently California and the one we heard yesterday, Pennsylvania have, are not there the lienholders the prior lienholders almost forced into bringing a procedure under 2410?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: They may well be and I think that for that -- that as I've indicated the statistics show that this is a usual form in which that is done.
That's right, that the -- the prior lienholder cannot hope to eliminate the federal lien merely by going through the state procedure.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well this bank for example could not under this kind of contract arrangement any longer protect its rights under the trust deed by the existing procedures for that it would have to bring the -- a litigation either in the California court or in the federal court to accomplish it, would they not?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Do you mean at this time after this or before?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If you're right, if you're are right in this case, if you're right in this case can Mr. Stewart any longer affect titles under trust deeds for his client and no matter what he did here?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It'll mean you'll have to bring a suit either in the California court or in the Federal District Court if he is not to follow the cumbersome foreclosure procedure that the State provides and such a suit will have to bring -- be one under 2410, would it not?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's right.
You -- you would have to follow these requirements.
You could either bring -- bring suit to foreclose.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, Mr. Friedman there wouldn't be -- there wouldn't be even by the most fanatic of the finder of constitutional question in anything and everything in the law, there wouldn't be a constitutional issue if Congress tomorrow but is there if you taking a little time off and it legislates -- legislative day passed a statute in effect that the state law and state procedure governing the disposition and satisfaction and displacement of junior lien shall apply to junior lien of the United States.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Oh no.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is there any -- there couldn't be one?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So the only question we have here is to interpret, is to define the content for -- what Mr. Stewart insists on quiet -- proceeding to quiet title, is that right?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well just to put it at how I put it --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You can put it differently, but isn't that -- isn't that the issue before us?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well it --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Whether because this is an honest to God prior to title proceeding cutting off junior lien from California, it governs junior liens of the United States.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: If I may that a little differently, Mr. Justice.
I think the question is whether the title can be quieted now because of what happened before.
In other words -- I -- their claim is not that in this suit the liens can be cut off.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I know I understand that.
Whether this is a quiet title proceeding within the meaning of 2410, you accept that?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No I can't Mr. Justice because this is a quiet title proceeding under 2410.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It is on the California law but not under 2410 under your argument.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Mr. Justice I think it's a -- an unsuccessful quiet title proceeding.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You're right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you, I think understand what you mean.
What you are saying is that they -- they do have a right to file a bill to quiet title which means that if they can win if it means you have no longer in a lien --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- on the merits.
You say on the merits, you still have a lien because they didn't give you the note -- make you a party as the statute required and therefore they lose their suit to quiet title on the merits.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Not because they're not authorized to file a suit, isn't that --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They're authorized to file a suit something that the quiet procedure -- quiet title from the California law may not satisfy the requirement implied or explicit of a federal statute where federal liens are involved --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well I -- I would equate in terms, Mr. Justice, these terms that the question is whether a quiet title suit may succeed on the basis of what has previously happened.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well of course if the United States can not file a quiet --and object to any kind of piece of paper being filed on a California court.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: You say that the procedure implied here by the bank was alright but it hasn't any substance on merits as such.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, you do admit that they foreclosed their mortgage -- the bank did foreclose its mortgage in accordance with the California law.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, that mortgage then became a spent instrument once that power of sale was exercised, didn't it?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: As far as the mortgages, as far as the mortgagor and the mortgagee, yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, you say that while you've argued that your lien is now to become a first lien you don't really mean that in answer to others of my brothers, but I want you to tell me now if you can how the bank's going about to get its money without first paying off what you say is now your first lien.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well that it could too, the one thing the bank could do is to bring a proceeding under 7424, which will be to have a validity of the Government's lien determined or on this proceeding I suppose, although the Court granted summary judgment, they might go back to the District Court and ask the District Court itself in accordance with alternative prayer for relief to decree a sale of the property, sale under the authorization of the Marshal.
Now if at that sale, if at that sale the property brings no more than the amount of their debt we're out.
We have no claim to anything more.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Or should the federal court go through a procedure -- same procedure between the central and local authorities even though the Government has an interest.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well I suppose because Congress has given us the right to move these cases into the federal court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But did it -- alright --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Now I just like to very briefly in closing point out that what we had here was the trust deed conveyed title to the trustee, but the California courts have said that this is a security title that's all they said and it's -- as a case it was developed in California.

Now the courts have treated it as a practical matter a mortgage and a deed of trust is very similar and what we really had here analytically I think is what we had yesterday in the Brosnan case that is, the indebtedness was created and in order to secure the payment of this indebtedness the debtor, the mortgagor gave to the mortgagee or the trustee or the beneficiary the power to apply the property, to sell the property and to apply the proceeds to the proceeds towards the discharge of his indebtedness, but they're attached to this property prior to the time of sale, this federal lien and this attached basically to the mortgagor or the taxpayer's interest in the property.

And under well established principles once the lien attaches to property when the property is sold and transferred it passes with the lien unless the act of sale itself operates to discharge the lien from the property.

As I've indicated we think it is clear that Congress has said that except when you -- or comply with the strict requirements of 2410, the State nonjudicial sales to which the United States is a party do not operate to eliminate and wipe out the federal liens on this real property and we therefore believe the judgment should be affirmed.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Stewart.

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice I thank you for the additional five minutes.

I should like to direct your attention to one reference which it seems to me demonstrates the utter inconsistency of the Government's position here and then I'll devote the rest of the five minutes to an effort to answer some of the questions that that were asked of my friend on the other side.
The reference is to a revenue ruling which is quoted on page 6 of the petitioner's main brief which is rather short and it seems to me feels directly with the question involved here.

It says, "Federal tax liens attach to property only to the extent of the delinquent taxpayer's interest therein where a taxpayer has only an option to purchase real estate" and this deals with an option now but it seems to me closely analogous to our situation here, “where the taxpayer has only an option to purchase real property at the time the federal tax lien arises, the lien attaches to the option, that is, to the interest of the taxpayer not to the real estate.
Where his rights under the option are terminable the Government's right by virtue of its lien upon the taxpayer's interest, are likewise terminable, being no greater than those of the taxpayer.”

Accordingly, when the taxpayer's rights under an option terminate after the federal tax lien has arisen the rights of the United States in the option also terminates since there is no longer any property in the option to which a lien may attach.

It seems to me sir you can apply that word for word, syllable for syllable to the situation here, the Government's lien attaches to the taxpayer's interest, a defeasible interest, something less than a total, free, and unencumbered fee title of the property and when that title is gone so is the Government's tax lien gone with it.
And now to go to the question that was asked of Mr. Friedman I believe by Mr. Justice Frankfurter, what could you do before 1924?
You couldn't do anything except buy the Government off because there was no procedure that was authorized.
Then came 2410, originally in a form, that authorized only a foreclosure suit.
Then we could get rid of them if we wanted to go three years, through three years of trouble and expense to do it.

Then came the amendment in 1942 to 2410 which if Your Honors agree with my contention here has simplified the procedure which was the only excuse for having that amendment, to permit another method not this complicated three-year proceeding but a simple method of going through the simple procedure recognized by most of the States.
Yes sir?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If -- if your view does not prevail, getting back to the question I ask Mr. Friedman --

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- your only alternative in the future in cases like this to follow that cumbersome three-year procedure you've described?

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: Unless we can deal with it administratively, sir, that's the only legal option we have.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But I don't quite follow that.
Now this -- this cumbersome procedure I gather is your state foreclosure proceeding.

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: That's -- that's correct sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And 2410 doesn't provide a --

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: Well 2410 is the same thing sir.
All 2410 does is prescribe certain standards of state foreclosure proceedings.
In other words, your state foreclosure proceeding must meet these tests of notice, right to redeem, and all the other things that that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Why does it take three years?
I don't follow that.

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: I can't tell you why sir except that it does, that this is our experience.
It has been a two years minimum, three years more normal.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean court congestion?

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: No sir it's the -- it's the -- well this is part of it, yes sir court congestion plus the year of right of redemption on the end of it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well if this be so if you went -- if you were in the federal court out there?

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The same thing.

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: Of course we have no right to go to the federal court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No I know you have to -- to move.

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: We have to start on the state court.
It is only when the -- when the Government removes us to the federal court that we get into the federal court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why did you say you have to foreclose the statute which specifically authorizes you to file a bill to quiet title?
You don't have to wait until you have sold it without notice.
You can file a bill to quiet title and give -- give a notice to the Government and test out its lien.

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: But if you'll get --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And if you're saying that they didn't have any remedy and then they give them a remedy to foreclose then they gave them foreclose, but they had to have the title (Inaudible) then they give him a remedy by quieting title and now you say that despite those things although they never had any before you can take the third remedy and let the state foreclose without notice, under the state law.
That's the same --

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: No Mr. Justice Black I -- I have to think I've not made my self clear, let me try.
The remedy to quiet title is not a procedure for settling liens and for determining who has what rights one against another.
It is a proceeding for determining what has been done heretofore.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why isn't that they have given you here in this statute where you did have a right to proceed by foreclosing, if they wanted to add to that so that you'd have another remedy, it's a federally created remedy to quiet title that this is in fact attacking this lien.
I -- I've had those kind of cases.
I don't see why you say that's not a legitimate kind of a lawsuit.

turn.speaker: samuel_b_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Samuel B. Stewart
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Black perhaps -- perhaps I'm wrong, perhaps -- perhaps the Court can straighten me off, but my interpretation of that is this that the approval of a quiet title procedure was necessarily an approval of quiet title procedure which exists under state law.
This is the only procedure to which we have access.
We could not get jurisdiction in the federal court on the ground that this involved a federal statute or -- or suit against the Government.
